Bug.Summery: [Clipboard] Eclipse occasionally hangs with presence of Galeon browser
Bug.WithStack:
Description: Eclipse occasionally hangs during Java/C++ development (using JDT and CDT) when Galeon is also running on the system. The hanging is not permanent, and Eclipse "comes back to life" after a time. The duration of the hang is variable and is on the order of minutes. The longest time I have experienced is around 20 minutes, and the shortest about 2-3 minutes. During the hang, no CPU, memory, or network resources are consumed (at least according to my system monitor), the harddisk is not in use, and 'top' reports that Eclipse is sleeping. The entire Eclipse GUI does not paint (refresh) during a hang.
Observations: I first noticed this problem when loading Eclipse after having started Galeon, and Eclipse would take an extremely long time to come up.
A low amount of free memory seems to aggravate the problem. In fact, adding -Xmx128M to the java command line reduced the frequency of the problem.
If Eclipse is started before Galeon, it comes up as expected, but may become unresponsive later, after Galeon has started.
Logging out and logging back in seems to aleviate the problem. That is, until Galeon is started again.
This problem also existed in earlier versions of Eclipse (specifically 2.1.1).
The problem does not appear while running Mozilla. The problem does not appear if Galeon has not been started. Closing Galeon (after the problem occurs) does not prevent the problem from future occurrence. Logging out and in again (which restarts X) is the only way I can find to make a clean start.
The problem seems unspecific. It sometimes occurs during plain typing, sometimes during CPU-intensive GUI-driven tasks, sometimes during simple GUI-driven tasks (e.g. right-click for context menu). It occurs independent of a particular component or plugin. However, it does seem to occur more frequently when attempting more CPU-intensive tasks like switching perspectives.
Suspicions: Is GTK the problem? (Galeon uses GTK.) Is there something Eclipse is waiting on? (a lock file or something, perhaps shared with Galeon, Gnome, or GTK?) Does this waiting time out, allowing Eclipse to "come back?" Is it a memory allocation problem? (e.g. Is Eclipse waiting for more memory to be allocated that is not allocated for some time?)
Versions: Galeon 1.2.13
Eclipse 3.0.1; build id: 200409161125 (same for JDT, of course)
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_01-b08) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_01-b08, mixed mode, sharing)
GTK+ 1.2.10
Red Hat 9 Linux 2.4.20-8 #1 Thu Mar 13 17:18:24 EST 2003 i686 athlon i386 GNU/Linux
XFree86 Version 4.3.0 (Red Hat Linux 9 release: 4.3.0-2.90.55)
Contact: Please direct any inquiries to sergei_francois (at) yahoo (dot) dom. I would be happy to provide additional information, but I don't know where to look, or even what would be helpful. -With gratitude, Aubrey First guess: galeon owns the X clipboard and is being unresponsive.
To find out what's going on, run eclipse from a terminal window, and look up the process ID of the java process from top or ps. When a hang occurs, do "kill -3 <pid_of_java>". This will ask the VM to print a stack trace to the terminal.
Do you have any clipboard managers running (like KDE's klipper)? Created attachment 22647 Java VM thread stack trace during problem
The full thread dump of the Java VM taken during a hang. In that stack trace, you are pasting something, and whatever it is asking for the clipboard from is taking a long time to provide it.
What did you have in your clipboard when you took this trace? (In reply to comment #1) I included the specified thread dump as an attachment (above).
> First guess: galeon owns the X clipboard and is being unresponsive.
It seems your guess may be correct. The trace says the main thread is waiting on the clipboard.
> Do you have any clipboard managers running (like KDE's klipper)?
I am not aware that I have any clipboard managers running. 'klipper' is not to be found in 'ps aux'. I have not knowingly started any clipboard managers. I would also be interested in knowing if this problem is as easily reproducable using a build of Eclipse 3.1. Created attachment 22743 Java thread dump during problem
(In reply to comment #3)
Here is another trace. This time I payed attention to the contents of my clipboard. (I couldn't remember the contents after submitting the previous trace, but it wasn't anything large or extraordinary, and they were long gone by the time I read your reply.)
The clipboard was empty. The paste menu item was disabled under Galeon, and neither Ctrl-V or middle-mouse-button yielded anything. Since logging in, I had only opened Galeon to check my e-mail, and had not copied or selected anything. I then proceeded to start eclipse (as always, from a terminal), which went through its first phase of startup, and then hung, leaving me with the splash screen. (This is a typical instance of the problem.) At that point, I examined the clipboard (by trying to paste) and made the trace.
Also, since Eclipse's GUI hadn't come up yet, I couldn't have been trying to paste anything. In fact, I can't remember any time that I experienced a hang that occurred while trying to cut/copy/paste something. They usually occur during startup, while doing a GUI intensive operation (e.g. perspective switch), activating a menu (right-click or menu bar), and I remember one day where it happened frequently during Java code updating -you know, coloring, fixing/finding errors, whatever "as you go" code analysis and compilation that goes on. That was the day that would have been most closely related to the clipboard. For example, paste a new method and then Eclipse hangs when doing the code analysis.
BTW, if you think this problem relates directly to the clipboard, I welcome suggestions for ways of examining the system clipboard. (Should I run 'klipper'? Is there a command line program to examine the X clipboard? Are there special cases for pasting that would lead me to believe the clipboard empty when it in reality wasn't?) Billy wrote a little application that will tell you who owns the clipboard:
http://vektor.ca/eclipse/xclipowner.c
See Bug 74498 (Comment #6) for more instructions on how to use this application.
When you hang, could you check who owns the clipboard and report it here? Created attachment 22866 The X clipboard owner and X window hierarchy
Here is the output of xclipowner: PRIMARY owner is 0x1a00506 ( ) SECONDARY has no owner. CLIPBOARD has no owner.
I will also include a java thread dump. The problem occurred in the same spot as before: after the splash screen and before the GUI comes up. Created attachment 22867 Java thread dump
This trace corresponds to the JVM when the X information was gathered (clipboard owner and window hierarchy dump). Did you have any text selected in Galeon? xclipowner indicates that Galeon is asserting ownership of the PRIMARY clipboard.
The problem you are seeing should be solved in Eclipse 3.1, which only checks PRIMARY when you actually hit the middle mouse button to paste it. (In reply to comment #10)
I have been using 3.1RC2 for 2 days running now, and I haven't experienced any hangs. So the problems appears to be fixed, although this is hard to confirm without a concrete test case, of course.
Out of curiosity, why does Eclipse wait for the clipboard contents when this can block and cause a hang? Seemingly it would make more sense for an asynchronous interface with the system clipboard. Then maybe the user could paste the empty string if the clipboard contents were not received within 1 second, or something similar. I understand the system clipboard uses a call back mechanism. Why couldn't this be used with Eclipse?
Anyway, I'm glad to hear that Eclipse only asks for the clipboard when necessary. Hanging during startup was certainly misleading in that you wouldn't expect it to try to fetch the clipboard contents until you had tried to paste something. While the X clipboard is asynchronous, many toolkits have synchronous APIs. Both Qt and Xt have blocking clipboard APIs, each with a 5 second timeout. GTK+ encourages applications to use the clipboard asynchronously, although this can lead to strange behaviour if applications are lagged. For example, try copying some text in your browser, suspend the browser process (^Z), and hit Ctrl+V five times in a gedit window. Then, resume the browser. It's a lot of fun.
The timeout in GTK+ for a hung application is 30 seconds, but it used to be five minutes: http://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=155428 (+ a debate on IRC)
Applications often check the clipboard contents to know if there is some MIME type they are interested in, and if so, they will enable the "Paste" action in their menus. Many views in Eclipse only respond to certain types, and so they have a tendancy to check the clipboard often.
While we still tend to check CLIPBOARD, we check PRIMARY (the middle-button paste buffer) only when you hit the middle mouse button. Could you try selecting some text in Galeon and pasting it many times over in eclipse? Does this cause a hang? (In reply to comment #12)
So, I tried selecting comment #12 (viewed with Galeon) and pasting it into a plain text editor in Eclipse. I tried it with both the middle mouse and Ctrl-V.
I could not get Eclipse to hang.
However, the insertion of text into the editor does not seem to scale well. I realize this is probably not your issue, but it is part of what I observed. If you think it would be worth passing on, please do. I thought I'd mention it because one of the themes for Eclipse 3 is scalability.
I pasted according to a quick rhythm. (I was listening to some bebop.) What happens (with both methods of pasting) is that the paste lags once in a while. The lag is characterized by a CPU spike. As more and more is pasted, the lags get more frequent. Once the editor has 5000-6000 lines in it, the paste lags about every other time. This was much more pronounced with the insertion point somewhere in the middle of the text rather than at the end.
Towards the end of the pasting experiment the CPU would be about 66% used with spikes (> 90%) according to the lags. I have an Athlon XP 2200 (1800 MHz), so this might not be as much of an issue for more modern hardware. I think it deserves mention, though, because the user will probably expect pasting to be a constant time operation (in proportion to the size of the text pasted, at least), and it appears that this is not the case, as my paste size stayed the same and the time it took to paste increased.
Scalability aside, unless you give me more tests to try, the clipboard problem seems to be solved.

I am not aware that I have any clipboard managers running. 'klipper' is not to be found in 'ps aux'. I have not knowingly started any clipboard managers. I would also be interested in knowing if this problem is as easily reproducable using a build of Eclipse 3.1. Created attachment 22743 Java thread dump during problem
(In reply to comment #3)
Here is another trace. This time I payed attention to the contents of my clipboard. (I couldn't remember the contents after submitting the previous trace, but it wasn't anything large or extraordinary, and they were long gone by the time I read your reply.)
The clipboard was empty. The paste menu item was disabled under Galeon, and neither Ctrl-V or middle-mouse-button yielded anything. Since logging in, I had only opened Galeon to check my e-mail, and had not copied or selected anything. I then proceeded to start eclipse (as always, from a terminal), which went through its first phase of startup, and then hung, leaving me with the splash screen. (This is a typical instance of the problem.) At that point, I examined the clipboard (by trying to paste) and made the trace.
Also, since Eclipse's GUI hadn't come up yet, I couldn't have been trying to paste anything. In fact, I can't remember any time that I experienced a hang that occurred while trying to cut/copy/paste something. They usually occur during startup, while doing a GUI intensive operation (e.g. perspective switch), activating a menu (right-click or menu bar), and I remember one day where it happened frequently during Java code updating -you know, coloring, fixing/finding errors, whatever "as you go" code analysis and compilation that goes on. That was the day that would have been most closely related to the clipboard. For example, paste a new method and then Eclipse hangs when doing the code analysis.
BTW, if you think this problem relates directly to the clipboard, I welcome suggestions for ways of examining the system clipboard. (Should I run 'klipper'? Is there a command line program to examine the X clipboard? Are there special cases for pasting that would lead me to believe the clipboard empty when it in reality wasn't?) Billy wrote a little application that will tell you who owns the clipboard:
http://vektor.ca/eclipse/xclipowner.c
See Bug 74498 (Comment #6) for more instructions on how to use this application.
When you hang, could you check who owns the clipboard and report it here? Created attachment 22866 The X clipboard owner and X window hierarchy
Here is the output of xclipowner: PRIMARY owner is 0x1a00506 ( ) SECONDARY has no owner. CLIPBOARD has no owner.
I will also include a java thread dump. The problem occurred in the same spot as before: after the splash screen and before the GUI comes up. Created attachment 22867 Java thread dump
This trace corresponds to the JVM when the X information was gathered (clipboard owner and window hierarchy dump). Did you have any text selected in Galeon? xclipowner indicates that Galeon is asserting ownership of the PRIMARY clipboard.
The problem you are seeing should be solved in Eclipse 3.1, which only checks PRIMARY when you actually hit the middle mouse button to paste it. (In reply to comment #10)
I have been using 3.1RC2 for 2 days running now, and I haven't experienced any hangs. So the problems appears to be fixed, although this is hard to confirm without a concrete test case, of course.
Out of curiosity, why does Eclipse wait for the clipboard contents when this can block and cause a hang? Seemingly it would make more sense for an asynchronous interface with the system clipboard. Then maybe the user could paste the empty string if the clipboard contents were not received within 1 second, or something similar. I understand the system clipboard uses a call back mechanism. Why couldn't this be used with Eclipse?
Anyway, I'm glad to hear that Eclipse only asks for the clipboard when necessary. Hanging during startup was certainly misleading in that you wouldn't expect it to try to fetch the clipboard contents until you had tried to paste something. While the X clipboard is asynchronous, many toolkits have synchronous APIs. Both Qt and Xt have blocking clipboard APIs, each with a 5 second timeout. GTK+ encourages applications to use the clipboard asynchronously, although this can lead to strange behaviour if applications are lagged. For example, try copying some text in your browser, suspend the browser process (^Z), and hit Ctrl+V five times in a gedit window. Then, resume the browser. It's a lot of fun.
The timeout in GTK+ for a hung application is 30 seconds, but it used to be five minutes: http://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=155428 (+ a debate on IRC)
Applications often check the clipboard contents to know if there is some MIME type they are interested in, and if so, they will enable the "Paste" action in their menus. Many views in Eclipse only respond to certain types, and so they have a tendancy to check the clipboard often.
While we still tend to check CLIPBOARD, we check PRIMARY (the middle-button paste buffer) only when you hit the middle mouse button. Could you try selecting some text in Galeon and pasting it many times over in eclipse? Does this cause a hang? (In reply to comment #12)
So, I tried selecting comment #12 (viewed with Galeon) and pasting it into a plain text editor in Eclipse. I tried it with both the middle mouse and Ctrl-V.
I could not get Eclipse to hang.
However, the insertion of text into the editor does not seem to scale well. I realize this is probably not your issue, but it is part of what I observed. If you think it would be worth passing on, please do. I thought I'd mention it because one of the themes for Eclipse 3 is scalability.
I pasted according to a quick rhythm. (I was listening to some bebop.) What happens (with both methods of pasting) is that the paste lags once in a while. The lag is characterized by a CPU spike. As more and more is pasted, the lags get more frequent. Once the editor has 5000-6000 lines in it, the paste lags about every other time. This was much more pronounced with the insertion point somewhere in the middle of the text rather than at the end.
Towards the end of the pasting experiment the CPU would be about 66% used with spikes (> 90%) according to the lags. I have an Athlon XP 2200 (1800 MHz), so this might not be as much of an issue for more modern hardware. I think it deserves mention, though, because the user will probably expect pasting to be a constant time operation (in proportion to the size of the text pasted, at least), and it appears that this is not the case, as my paste size stayed the same and the time it took to paste increased.
Scalability aside, unless you give me more tests to try, the clipboard problem seems to be solved.

Bug.Summery: [KeyBindings] preference page: Cannot assign shortcut to Show Navigator View
Bug.WithStack:
In 3.0 I could assign a shortcut to the Show Navigator View command. Now that I upgrade, the shortcut seems to be still there (see 1st screenshot attached) but doesn't work, and I don't see the command in Preferences/Keys (see 2nd screenshot attached).
Alex Created attachment 22579 Windows menu Created attachment 22580 Preferences / Keys The second screenshot doesn't show the correct category. The "Show Navigator View" command is in the "Views" category. Doug, I don't see that in the "views" category either. See the 3rd screenshot attached (Preferences / Keys / Views).
Alex Created attachment 29450 Preferences / Keys / Views Can you attach your "<workspace>/.metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime/.settings/org.eclipse.ui.workbench.prefs" file? Created attachment 29575 My org.eclipse.ui.workbench.prefs, as requested Doug, sure, I have attached that file to the bug.
Alex
Sorry, I should have realized this earlier. You should bind to "Show View (View: Navigator)" in the keys preference page. Eclipse 3.1 introduced parameterized commands, which made the old commands obsolete. There are some open bugs with the migration (Bug 89843, Bug 90959).
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 89843 *** There you go! Thank you Douglas for answering this one.
Alex

Bug.Summery: Bad pratice on handling NPE in TasksWizardFragment
Bug.WithStack:
Concerning about TasksWizardFragment in package org.eclipse.wst.server.ui.internal.wizard.fragment
The method TasksWizardFragment.isSelected() is called frequently (10 times per expanding a node in the server view).
The code test try to test a boolean value bind to a map. However, it relies on a call all try block to handle that the boolean may not exist.
I see no reason that we can't do better.
======= stack trace ====== java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.wst.server.ui.internal.wizard.fragment.TasksWizardFragment$TaskInfo.isSelected(TasksWizardFragment.java:51) at org.eclipse.wst.server.ui.internal.wizard.fragment.TasksWizardFragment.performFinish(TasksWizardFragment.java:206) at org.eclipse.wst.server.ui.internal.wizard.TaskWizard.executeTask(TaskWizard.java:241) at org.eclipse.wst.server.ui.internal.wizard.TaskWizard$2.run(TaskWizard.java:201) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.run(Workspace.java:1719) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.run(Workspace.java:1739) at org.eclipse.wst.server.ui.internal.wizard.page.WorkspaceRunnableAdapter.run(WorkspaceRunnableAdapter.java:35) at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run(ModalContext.java:113) Fix dropped to HEAD, will be tagged for I-build. Tim, thank! You're fast. :-) Verified fixed by code review. Closing.

Bug.Summery: [Build] Modify Agent Controller make files to be independent of the build environment.
Bug.WithStack:
Modify Agent Controller make files to be independent of the build environment.
For example, the current Agent Controller make files require that the CommonBaseEvent.lib file is located under the ..\..\..\cbe directory. Also, these make files require the build environment to contain a defined directory structure for its dependencies.
Users should be able to extract the module from CVS and with the appropriate instructions (e.g. org.eclipse.tptp.platform.agentcontroller\src- native\collection\README.txt), build the Agent Controller but simply setting environment variables to include dependencies (e.g. CBE, Xerces, JRE, etc.).
The same issue may apply to the new Agent Controller. Also, the two Agent Controller implementations should have the same format/structure for their build readmes (e.g. org.eclipse.tptp.platform.agentcontroller\src- native\collection\README.txt and org.eclipse.tptp.platform.agentcontroller\src- native-new\bin\readme.txt). Sri, this is referring to the new Agent Controller makefiles. Can you please assign you one of your team members? Thanks. Andy,
This seems to be relevant as native CBE is integrated into AC logging infrastructur.
-Sri This is build and packaging issue for the new agent controller. Byron will look into it for 4.1 I3. The Agent Controller build now gets the CommonBaseEvent.h file from the native logging source. This fix only solves locating the the native Common Base Event header file and is undocumented. There are several other issues outstanding. As such, reopening. This defect should not be split for both Agent Controllers since one of the requirements is to ensure the structure of both build readmes should be similar so there are no usability issues when users want to build both. Ultimately, I would like to see the format used in the old Agent Controller but I will leave the format up to you.
The outstanding issues are:
-The two Agent Controller implementations should have the same format/structure for their build readmes (e.g. org.eclipse.tptp.platform.agentcontroller\src- native\collection\README.txt and org.eclipse.tptp.platform.agentcontroller\src- native-new\bin\readme.txt).
-The two Agent Controller implementation's make files require all of their dependencies to be in defined directory structure in the build environment (e.g. native Common Base Event CommonBaseEvent.lib file is located under the ..\..\..\cbe directory). Users should be able to extract the module from CVS and with the appropriate instructions, build the specified Agent Controller by simply setting environment variables to include dependencies (e.g. CBE, Xerces, JRE, etc.).
Reassigning to Randy since he is handling build issues for new AC. Randy please set target for when this can be accomplished. corrected target, from 4.1i2 to 4.2i2. For the new technology AC, I've made the builds depend upon the user having a CBE SDK downloaded with the environment variable CBE_SDK_HOME pointing to that installation, much as we do for XercesC and Java. I've documented this change in our readme.txt, and notified our team (Intel folk and Samson) of those changes.
If the README/readme is still an issue, file a separate bugzilla; the premise behind the original bugzilla is now met. Realize that (1) we don't particularly like where our readme is or how it's named, so that change would be welcomed, (2) many changes have been made since the original bugzilla that brings the readmes closer together anyway, and (3) I really don't feel comfortable going over to src-native and changing the README (which, by the way, is woefully out of date!). The ultimate solution will be arrived at when there is once again "one readme" as the new technology AC becomes the AC for all platforms. Verified in the TPTP V4.2.0 (TPTP-4.2.0-200604030200) driver.

Bug.Summery: [arch] webbrowser plugin no longer needed
Bug.WithStack:
As discussed with Tim, since 3.1 base eclipse picked up web browser API, and there's no longer any API being proposed here, this plugin is a good candidate to eliminate.
I marked as "major" because is important to get rid of this soon, to avoid last minute churn. Plugin removed. The content has been merged into a new package in the org.eclipse.wst.server.util plugin. * Moved code, icons, contents of plugin.xml and tests over, etc. * Removed webbrowser tests * Fixed wst, wst.server, and wst.tests features * Tagged and checked in everything

Bug.Summery: [WorkbenchParts] Disposed PartPane may still be referring to workbench objects other than the page
Bug.WithStack:
build N20050607
When and editor reference is disposed, it still hangs onto its pane, which refers to the workbook etc.
A disposed editor reference should be as lightweight as possible, with no refs to other workbench objects.
I'm trying to improve the editor navigation history to handle multiple editors on the same input better, and to do so I need to hang onto the editor reference, but history entries outlive editors, so it will be a common case for them to refer to disposed editor references. I agree that it should be as lightweight as possible, but it needs to hold onto the PartPane in order to respect its invariants (for example, getPane is always expected to return non-null).
Eclipse 3.0 did not require the pane to exist in all situations, but that forced all callers to deal with the null case (which was not always possible, required duplicate state, and introduced quite a few bugs).
The pane itself can (and should) clean up all its references when disposed. When disposed, the pane's only reference should be to the workbench page (which would be necessary for the reference anyway) - not to the stack.
That said, I would not recommend holding onto a disposed reference in any avoidable circumstance. Perhaps we should chat about your use-case?
Unless we can refactor to make the getPane method unnecessary or impossible to call on a disposed reference, clearing the pane pointer is INVALID. However if the disposed pane is still referring to the stack (or any large workbench object other than the page), this is a valid bug. Therefore, I'm renaming and keeping this open.
I'm pretty sure the pane was still hanging onto the workbook.
Nick, now that I think about it more, it should be possible to clear the pane pointer. The pane is used for managing the pane within the workbench layout, and a disposed reference is a reference that is no longer in the layout... so there should be no valid reason for asking for the pane from a disposed reference.
However, there is still client code that hangs onto disposed references and tries to pass them back to workbench APIs. In order to make this change, we'd need to make sure that all of these APIs recover gracefully from recieving a disposed reference rather than throwing a NPE the first time they ask for the pane.
Is this still a problem in 3.3?
PW
Changes requested on bug 193523

Bug.Summery: Incorrect stack representation with same named targets in subbuilds
Bug.WithStack:
The AntDebugState incorrectly assumes that target names will be unique. They are unique per project but subbuilds introduce multiple projects and therefore target name collisions can occur.
This results in incorrect stack representation for target dependencies for the subbuild.
For example with a breakpoint on line 6 of antBuildFile.xml the stack looks like: Thread [Ant Build] (Suspended) depends: echo line: 6 default line: 2 default: ant line: 12 default line: 2
===callExternal.xml==== <project name="internalProject" default="entry"> <target name="entry" depends="default"> <echo>entry</echo> </target> <target name="default"> <echo>default</echo> <ant antfile="antBuildFile.xml"></ant> </target> </project>
=====antBuildFile.xml===== <project name="externalProject" default="default"> <target name="default" depends="depends"> <echo>default</echo> </target> <target name="depends"> <echo>depends!</echo> </target> </project> Changes released to AntDebugState to retain the target build sequence per target per project. Please verify Kevin. This has been fixed since N20050609...forgot to move the bug... verified
Bug.WithOutStack:
The AntDebugState incorrectly assumes that target names will be unique. They are unique per project but subbuilds introduce multiple projects and therefore target name collisions can occur.
This results in incorrect stack representation for target dependencies for the subbuild.
For example with a breakpoint on line 6 of antBuildFile.xml the stack looks like: Thread [Ant Build] (Suspended) depends: echo line: 6 default line: 2 default: ant line: 12 default line: 2
===callExternal.xml==== <project name="internalProject" default="entry"> <target name="entry" depends="default"> <echo>entry</echo> </target> <target name="default"> <echo>default</echo> <ant antfile="antBuildFile.xml"></ant> </target> </project>
=====antBuildFile.xml===== <project name="externalProject" default="default"> <target name="default" depends="depends"> <echo>default</echo> </target> <target name="depends"> <echo>depends!</echo> </target> </project> Changes released to AntDebugState to retain the target build sequence per target per project. Please verify Kevin. This has been fixed since N20050609...forgot to move the bug... verified

Bug.Summery: Several warnings in auto generated code in jspel code.

source_code.code: static private final class LookaheadSuccess extends java.lang.Error { }

Lines.Line: 1. WARNING in
/home/build-home/build-current-I/workdir/plugins/org.eclipse.jst.jsp.core/src/org/eclipse/jst/jsp/core/internal/java/jspel/JSPELParser.java
(at line 1371)
The serializable class LookaheadSuccess does not declare a static final

Bug.Summery: (Test) documentation clarifcation needed for URL test section Creating a test deployment
Bug.WithStack:
In the heading for Creating a test deployment it states: You must create a deployment before you can run a test. This seems to be misleading. If you are running a local deployment, this is selectable (does not need to be created). That is, I found : Select the test suite. From the menu bar, click Run > Run. The Run dialog box opens. In the Configurations pane on the left, click Hyades URL Test. To create a new configuration, click the New button on the bottom left. A new test configuration, initially named New_Configuration, is created. Change the name. (As: Config4HTTP) In the Select Test to run pane in the middle listing all projects in the workspace, navigate to the project containing the test to run and select it. In the Select a deployment pane on the right listing select local deployment. ( This was selectable, I did not create it. ) Moving to 4.0 because 3.3 is closed for everything except stop-ship defects. Deferring because this is online documentation and it's too late for 4.0. Alex, please set the target milestone to something that you think is realistic. Thanks. Reassigning to the default component owner as per email with Alex Nolan. Fix checked in and will be in the Sept 30 1:00 AM build. ACTION: Please verify/close this defect. Closing by default since not closed by the originator in the 7+ months since being resolved.
Please reopen if the issue is still present in the latest TPTP release or the resolution is not correct.

If you are running a local deployment, this is selectable (does not need to be created). That is, I found : Select the test suite. From the menu bar, click Run > Run. The Run dialog box opens. In the Configurations pane on the left, click Hyades URL Test. To create a new configuration, click the New button on the bottom left. A new test configuration, initially named New_Configuration, is created. Change the name. (As: Config4HTTP) In the Select Test to run pane in the middle listing all projects in the workspace, navigate to the project containing the test to run and select it. In the Select a deployment pane on the right listing select local deployment. ( This was selectable, I did not create it. ) Moving to 4.0 because 3.3 is closed for everything except stop-ship defects. Deferring because this is online documentation and it's too late for 4.0. Alex, please set the target milestone to something that you think is realistic. Thanks. Reassigning to the default component owner as per email with Alex Nolan. Fix checked in and will be in the Sept 30 1:00 AM build. ACTION: Please verify/close this defect. Closing by default since not closed by the originator in the 7+ months since being resolved.
Please reopen if the issue is still present in the latest TPTP release or the resolution is not correct.

Bug.Summery: Collapsing an expanded tree item after computing sizes crashes the VM
Bug.WithStack:
I have some code that computes tree sizes on GTK+ (by walking the items) and then calls layout on the parent component. When I close an item that has been opened the VM crashes. The same code works fine on Win32 and OS X. Created attachment 22581 The .log file created after the bug described above Note: Crash was with GTK+ 2.4.14.
I wrote a simple example and could not cause the crash. Is there any way you could provide code to reproduce the problem? Also, does it happen every time? Could you comment out parts of the code (maybe, don't call layout()) and see if it still happens? The crash doesn't show much. It's in the event loop. Aaron: Any update on this? Sorry, I have nothing more. We are in crunch time and I haven't had time to focus on it. I should have time to reevaluate it and create a test case in a couple of weeks. The code base has changed significantly since this bug was reported. If it is still happening for you, please reopen this bug report.

I have some code that computes tree sizes on GTK+ (by walking the items) and then calls layout on the parent component. When I close an item that has been opened the VM crashes. The same code works fine on Win32 and OS X. Created attachment 22581 The .log file created after the bug described above Note: Crash was with GTK+ 2.4.14.
I wrote a simple example and could not cause the crash. Is there any way you could provide code to reproduce the problem? Also, does it happen every time? Could you comment out parts of the code (maybe, don't call layout()) and see if it still happens? The crash doesn't show much. It's in the event loop. Aaron: Any update on this? Sorry, I have nothing more. We are in crunch time and I haven't had time to focus on it. I should have time to reevaluate it and create a test case in a couple of weeks. The code base has changed significantly since this bug was reported. If it is still happening for you, please reopen this bug report.

Bug.Summery: "Text editor" and "Property editor" could display Chinese characters correctly
Bug.WithStack:
I am running Eclipse 3.1 RC1, on windows 2000 English version, when I open properties files containing chinese character, it could not display the correct text. The property files is just simple text file, I also attached a sample file.
though I report in version 3.1 RC1, this problem is same in Eclise V3.0,
JDT's Java Editor doesn't have this problem. Created attachment 22584 a sample property file that containing chinese characters
a sample property file that containing chinese characters Created attachment 22585 the display in my machine
above is the original text, below is what it is displayed in property editor, You gave to install Chinese otherwise this won't work in Windows2000. On WinXP you can simply add the additional input languages and fonts. I do have installed chinese input language, 'cause in windows explorer, all chinese filenames could be displayed, and also i have input chinese input languages,
just as i mentioned, JDT's Java Editor just could display chinese characters correctly in the same machine. but neithor "Text Editor" nor "Property Editor" could work
Created attachment 22587 Regional Options Setting in Control Panel
Regional Options Setting in Control Panel Check whether they use the same font as the Java editor. Created attachment 22590 JAVA editor and Properties text font setting,
JAVA editor and Properties text font setting, which is same to text editor's font setting Created attachment 22591 Text editor's font setting
Text editor's font setting, which is GBK, if text editor does use this setting - *GBK*, it will be OK to display Chinese character.
I also changed to UTF-8, UTF-16, etc, but also could not work OK, I now see what happens. It's about the *encoding* not the font. If you create new properties, Java or text files they get the content types default encoding:
*.properties files: ISO-8859-1 *.java: non / platform default
so, it's not about the editor but about what encoding is used. Try this: create a file in the Java editor which looks good, save and open with either the Text or Properties edtior. Created attachment 22592 the properties file in hex string
another thing i just noticed is: the file containing Chinese Characters in the properties file which I created outside Eclipse could not display correctly, but when I input Chinese characters in the *Property Editor*, Chinese Character could be inputed also displayed OK, without any problem, but when I close the file in Eclipse, and open again, the place which would be chinese characters were replaced by two "??",
the attached is the hex string of the file after I saved.
So, it seems that when the file is saved, some encoding conversion has been done to it, but failed to convert to the corrent encode.
I just quite puzzled why in Java Editor, no this problem. I can input Chinese Characters, save, open, all fine. Hi, Daniel Megert:
I just input some chinese characters inside the .java file, close it, then open with text editor, OK, no problem, the characters I input could be displayed OK. vice verse, I create a new text in the Eclipse environment, by New-> Simple -> Untitled Text File, input some Chinese Characters, save to disk, close, open, also OK, no problem.
But if the file was created outside Eclipse beforehand, It will failed by the same operation.
you right, its an encoding problem,
The problem is that if the encoding can't be determined from the file the default is used: select the file in the Navigator or Package Exlporer and see what encoding is used. *.properties files have ISO-8859-1 encoding per default and hence you can't type in special chars. You can change this by changing the default encoding for the properties file content type but that's not recommended since Java properties files are speced to have ISO-8859-1 encoding.
Note that you can also set the default encoding on folders and files but that changing the encodign *does not* convert existing files. OK. i see.

Bug.Summery: "search scope for completion proposal" ignored completely
Bug.WithStack:
"search scope for completion proposal" -> "search curren file and included files" absolutely without effect, not working at all. org.eclipse.cdt-3.0.0-I200506070932-linux.x86.tar.gz Methinks Doug needs to clean up some UI for M7.
when is m7 sheduled? btw: which configuration-options exactly are responsible for auto-completion? I have not implemented auto-completion in the new content assist. I never appreciated the completion popup in my face at seemingly random times. If content assist was faster, it might be worth it. But for now it is not. I'll clean up the UI for RC1. This includes paying attention to the scope. I'll probably remove the configurability around auto-completion since I don't want to turn it on at this point. > since I don't want to turn it on at this point. what exactly does that mean? i'm a big fan of autocompletion (maybe i am corrupted by java ;-) so disabling it will definitevely keep me off from using eclipse :-( Yes, you are spoiled by the JDT. The CDT can take up to three seconds to present the proposals. Sometimes it's just faster to type it in yourself, in which case auto completion will just get in your way.
If this is all that's keeping you off using Eclipse, then we've done a pretty good job ;-) well ... it's not really all -- the last builds i tried was really slow and ate all of my cpu, but this (reported already) me be fixed rather soon ... but missing autocompletion, uhh ;-)
btw: is it possible to reply to bugzilla's mails? i tried once and it didn't work but maybe i did something wrong. (In reply to comment #4) > I'll clean up the UI for RC1. This includes paying attention to the scope. I'll > probably remove the configurability around auto-completion since I don't want to > turn it on at this point.
I just ran across this bug myself after installing CDT M7. I can only ask that you do NOT remove this functionality. For people who have fast machines, it's not THAT much slower than the JDT. I think this is just a matter of preference, and if someone doesn't like using it, they can turn it off. How about just disabling the feature by default? I personally find it annoying to type CTRL+SPACE every time I want content assist.
BTW, why is it slower than JDT? Does it not use the same technology?
thanks,
Barry
No, they don't use the same technology. Java parsers generally don't parse C++. Java doesn't have a preprocessor and, thus, inclusions. Parsing C++ is always slower than Java, no matter what tool you are looking at.
I'll see what I can do about enabling auto-completion as an option. But for the life of me I can't see the value in auto completion. It's faster to type the Ctrl-Space than to wait the 500ms for auto completion to kick in, no? But why does it have to use 500ms? You can set it to zero. Why is CTRL+SPACE faster than typing . -> or :: I don't get what you are saying at all.
But thanks for looking into enabling it!
-Barry This is going to be risky to fix in RC1. I'll do it right after. O.K. Completion now only uses search when "search current project" is selected. It actually skips by the time consuming parse in that scenario as well. But it does leave out anything local or unsaved/unindexed. I am just waiting on 102779 to actually search the current project instead of the whole workspace.
Autoactivation has also been re-engaged. All done. Search works quite nicely in content assist now. Great! I will check it in RC2. BTW, is there a mailing list I can get on that just notifies when there is a new release available?
thanks,
Barry
Nope. I'll announce on the cdt-dev list and the cdt newsgroup.

Bug.Summery: [Perspectives] [RCP] Standalone notitle views position toolbar incorrectly
Bug.WithStack:
N20050606-0010
Load the org.eclipse.ui.tests plugin and open the UI Test Standalone View Perspective 2. Notice that several of the views have a toolbar
The toolbar is supposed to be hidden for standalone views with no title. Created attachment 22589 Screenshot of the bogus toolbars If the view has toolbar contributions, they should be shown, just as with regular views. What was the behaviour in 3.0?
Although this may just be a miscommunication, I recall this being the intended behavior in the original design discussions. I'm starting to feel like the intended behavior for notitle views has become a moving target. Could we please spell it out somewhere?
Really, I'm not making this up. showTitle=false just means no titlebar, and no system buttons for close etc. If there are ISV toolbar or menu contributions, they should be shown. The intent is to expose the full view functionality, except for the titlebar. I don't think the toolbar or view menu were ever a concern for the original driving use case (the preview pane in LWP). Matt? In that case, where are they supposed to go and what should they look like? I'd vote for something as close to the regular layout as possible E.g. in the default presentation, toolbar at top, right aligned, with view menu to the right of that, like it would flow if they were forced to wrap for a regular view.
Re comment #5, yes this is expected behavior and not an issue for the LWP use case.
I agree with Nick's suggestiong in comment #7. I'd like to consider this one for RC3.
there do not seem to be any users of this (Stand-alone + toolbar), deferring to 3.2 I just want to say that i'm trying to use this feature until i found this bug report, so please don't defer it any longer Changing title to reflect the actual problem. Toolbars are shown (correctly) but are not positioned correctly. The doc (and comments here) seem to say that toolbar and menu contributions will always be shown. Using Build id: N20060212-0010 on Mac OS X 10.4.4, I don't see view menus and toolbars with addStandaloneView() unless I set showTitle=true.
I could not find the UI Test Standalone View Perspective 2 (looks like it was deleted?), so I tried a basic test. Create a new plug-in project using the template "RCP application with a view". It starts with no menus or toolbars, and uses addStandaloneView(showTitle=false).
At the bottom of View.createPartControl(), I added an Action: getViewSite().getActionBars().getToolBarManager().add(new Action() { public void run() { System.out.println("action activated."); } }) ;
No toolbar shows up. Then I changed showTitle to true -- and the action shows up on the toolbar, along with what looks like a title bar (see attachment). Given the documentation for IPageLayout and the comments here, I expected the toolbar to always be there, whether showTitle was true or false.
Created attachment 34896 toolbar after setting showTitle=true Is this still a problem in 3.3?
PW
I performed the test described in comment 13 using 3.3 M2 (I20060922-0010) on Mac OS X 10.4.7 and Java 1.5.0. The behavior was the same as that described in comment 13. The action does not appear unless showTitle is set to true. problem exist PW
I can confirm that the problem still exists as of Eclipse 3.4 M2
Boris and I both agree that if a view has declared menu and/or toolbar items that they should be available regardless of the state of the 'showTitle' flag.
What this would amount to is to use the same layout we get when the title (tab) area is too small to contain the TB and menu chevron (i.e. they show up to the right of the 'message' if there's enough space and below it otherwise.
Paul, can you confirm that this type of view still -uses- a CTabFolder?
Created attachment 107339 image of toolbar in standalone project explorer
I just wanted to confirm that this is still a problem. The attached screenshot shows the toolbar rendered on top of the view's content. In this case I'm running eclipse 3.4 and the view is the Common Navigator's project explorer ("org.eclipse.ui.navigator.ProjectExplorer").
Are there plans to fix this? In my use case the ideal solution would be to add a #showToolbar (the same as #showTitlebar) that would let me turn off the view's toolbar. However, I understand that is unlikely to be the accepted solution.
The minimum solution for me is to at least render the toolbar in the proper location. If no one is planning to work on this then I could try to find time to look into it. *** Bug 239359 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I can confirm this bug exist in 3.4.0 Build id: I20080617-2000 This problem still exists in 3.5 Created attachment 179960 Screenshot depicting the problem in question.
My 'Progress' view's toolbar ends up being way over in the top left hand side by the 'Package Explorer'.

Bug.WithOutStack:
N20050606-0010
Load the org.eclipse.ui.tests plugin and open the UI Test Standalone View Perspective 2. Notice that several of the views have a toolbar
The toolbar is supposed to be hidden for standalone views with no title. Created attachment 22589 Screenshot of the bogus toolbars If the view has toolbar contributions, they should be shown, just as with regular views. What was the behaviour in 3.0?
Although this may just be a miscommunication, I recall this being the intended behavior in the original design discussions. I'm starting to feel like the intended behavior for notitle views has become a moving target. Could we please spell it out somewhere?
Really, I'm not making this up. showTitle=false just means no titlebar, and no system buttons for close etc. If there are ISV toolbar or menu contributions, they should be shown. The intent is to expose the full view functionality, except for the titlebar. I don't think the toolbar or view menu were ever a concern for the original driving use case (the preview pane in LWP). Matt? In that case, where are they supposed to go and what should they look like? I'd vote for something as close to the regular layout as possible E.g. in the default presentation, toolbar at top, right aligned, with view menu to the right of that, like it would flow if they were forced to wrap for a regular view.
Re comment #5, yes this is expected behavior and not an issue for the LWP use case.
I agree with Nick's suggestiong in comment #7. I'd like to consider this one for RC3.
there do not seem to be any users of this (Stand-alone + toolbar), deferring to 3.2 I just want to say that i'm trying to use this feature until i found this bug report, so please don't defer it any longer Changing title to reflect the actual problem. Bug.Summery: "c++ indexer problem"
Bug.WithStack:
created a new class (Q01) from scratch -- in q01.h "class" is marked red, error mark says "c++ indexer problem: attempt to use symbol failed: class". what? in q01.cpp constructor got an error mark saying "c++ indexer problem: attempt to use symbol failed: Q01". what? indexer is "original c/c++ indexer".
org.eclipse.cdt-3.0.0-I200506070932-linux.x86.tar.gz Original Indexer will no longer exist in CDT M7. Pls re-open w/a complete code example if the problem still exists w/DOM AST Indexer & a project that is properly set up (w/include paths). does that mean dom ast is the preferred indexer? btw: what functionality exactly does the indexer provide? is it responsible for autocompletion? not really. the indexer is used to locate declarations and references of names in code. content assist can augment its results using the index, but it does not always.
Bug.WithOutStack:
created a new class (Q01) from scratch -- in q01.h "class" is marked red, error mark says "c++ indexer problem: attempt to use symbol failed: class". what? in q01.cpp constructor got an error mark saying "c++ indexer problem: attempt to use symbol failed: Q01". what? indexer is "original c/c++ indexer".

Pls re-open w/a complete code example if the problem still exists w/DOM AST Indexer & a project that is properly set up (w/include paths). does that mean dom ast is the preferred indexer? btw: what functionality exactly does the indexer provide? is it responsible for autocompletion? not really. the indexer is used to locate declarations and references of names in code. content assist can augment its results using the index, but it does not always.

Bug.Summery: All types search job shouldn't create images in non UI thread
Bug.WithStack:
RC1
Although SWT supports creating images in non UI threads there is a limitation to it on Motif. When no event loop is active this can result in a deadlock. To avoid this the search job should only create the descriptors and the real image should be fetched in the UI thread. Fixed for RC2
When verifying the bug test that the icons show up for element when the dialog opens (e.g. history elements exist), and for history element and search index matches when a pattern got entered verifying... Verified that icons show up for history items (no pattern), and for matches in the history as well as all other types.
Verified on Linux-GTK and Linux-Motif.
Bug.WithOutStack:
RC1
Although SWT supports creating images in non UI threads there is a limitation to it on Motif. When no event loop is active this can result in a deadlock. To avoid this the search job should only create the descriptors and the real image should be fetched in the UI thread. Fixed for RC2
When verifying the bug test that the icons show up for element when the dialog opens (e.g. history elements exist), and for history element and search index matches when a pattern got entered verifying... Verified that icons show up for history items (no pattern), and for matches in the history as well as all other types.
Verified on Linux-GTK and Linux-Motif.

1. get a new drop
2. import existing unshared plug-ins as binary projects (not linked)
==> auto-build is started and at the end my workspace has no compile errors
1) Binary projects with linked contents
2) Binary projects
3) Projects with source folders
4) Binary projects
- importing a second time does not fix the problem
- the projects are imported correctly: clean and full build fixes the problem
- did you import the required plug-ins as binary projects (not linked)?
- I have disabled all external plug-ins on the PDE Target platform pref page
- I'm just re-importing right now...
What might also be important: after the first full import of the required
plug-ins shut down and restart. Then import the existing binary projects (not
linked) again.
Re-importing once imported build X and running on X seems not to reproduce the
problem. I'll let you know tomorrow morning what happened when I started with
Imported using N20050609-0010 and it worked. The difference to when I reported
this bug is that I waited several minutes until the jobs view calmed down before
importing.

Bug.WithStack:
N20050608-0010 I have auto-build on. Until this week I could 0. have dev workspace without compile errors 1. get a new drop 2. import existing unshared plug-ins as binary projects (not linked) ==> auto-build is started and at the end my workspace has no compile errors This is no longer the case importing N20050608-0010 with N20050608-0010: the build starts but it is not capable of incrementally build my workspace. Errors remain saying "The project A cannot be built its prerequisite B is built." for most of the projects. - importing a second time does not fix the problem - the projects are imported correctly: clean and full build fixes the problem Marking as 'major' since it turns a completely fine workspace in one full of errors and requires me to do a full build. when autobuild is on, PDE imports the projects into the workspace and that's it. PDE is totally out of the picture after that. Resource notifications and the java builder take care of the rest. Whether a build is needed and/or what kind of build is needed is totally up to the compiler. Cannot reproduce with N20050608-0010 + JDT/Core HEAD. I had two plugins from CVS jdt.core and jdt.ui ones. I first import other required plugins and build finished normally without any error. Then I import all other plugins and, again, build finished fine... Can you make a second try tomorrow with N20050609-0010 build (if usable)? Thx mmh, maybe I misunderstood your steps but to me it looks like you performed a completely different test case: you imported plug-ins that did not yet exist in your workspace while I had all those plug-ins already and I re-imported them. - did you import the required plug-ins as binary projects (not linked)? - I have disabled all external plug-ins on the PDE Target platform pref page - I'm just re-importing right now... What might also be important: after the first full import of the required plug-ins shut down and restart. Then import the existing binary projects (not linked) again. Re-importing once imported build X and running on X seems not to reproduce the problem. I'll let you know tomorrow morning what happened when I started with N20050609-0010 and import N20050609-0010. Imported using N20050609-0010 and it worked. The difference to when I reported this bug is that I waited several minutes until the jobs view calmed down before importing. Whenever I switch to a new version my workspace seems to do a (full?) build. I was probably importing while there were still some build and/or other init jobs running. You're right. When I did my test, plugins I imported didn't exist in my workspace. So, I redo some tests this morning using build N20050609-0010. In my workspace, I initially had jdt.core and jdt.ui plugins loaded. I performed several imports for all required plugins (40) of these jdt plugins. Here are these imports: 1) Binary projects with linked contents 2) Binary projects 3) Projects with source folders 4) Binary projects Of course I had set auto-build on before and if import 1) didn't override existing plugins as they were not in my initial workspace, imports 2), 3) and 4) are obviously re-import and look like your initial test scenario (although it was not really obvious that it was a re-import... ;-)). Then, I never get any problem at the end of auto-build, even if I didn't have wait long time between each re-import. So, I think we agree to close this as WORKSFORME PS: The auto-build is due to new build state version number (see What's New section in our buildnotes_jdt-core.html): ...
  • The build state version number has changed. A full build of all projects in the workspace will be triggered upon startup if autobuild is on, or on the next build if autobuild is off.
    • ... To verify I just ran a similar scenario again without problems.

Bug.Summery: Add support for Mac OSX (X86/Intel)

Stacktrace.Reason: The activator org.eclipse.ui.internal.WorkbenchPlugin for bundle org.eclipse.ui.workbench is invalid

Lines.Line: 1) it seems like some of you were able to get it working on your intel iMacs. Could someone please give a "dummy's version" step-by-step of how to properly intall it (with links to relevant files)
2) could I cause problems by running this "fix" - i.e. should I just wait until the next version of eclipse is released that works automatically with this new system?
3) if I should wait, any estimates of how long that would be (days? weeks? months?)
4) Are there any other IDE's that are known to work well with the intel mac that I could use in the meantime?
0. Configure DB driver in Preferences > MyEclipseIDE >
Database Explorer > Drivers:
- MySQL Connector/J Driver
- add library, mysql-connector-java-3.1.1.jar
- driver class name is set to com.mysql.jdbc.Driver
1. Open DB Browser view
2. Open New Database Profile dialog
3. Enter everything up to "Password"
4. Type password.
- MySQL Connector/J Driver
- add library, mysql-connector-java-3.1.1.jar
- driver class name is set to com.mysql.jdbc.Driver
- pass SWT.PASSWORD on Text creation and stop calling Text.setEchoChar(...), or
- call Text.setEchoChar(...) and fill the character in both byte halfs of the 16bit character,
i.e. setEchoChar((c << 8) + c)

I searched for "Universal Binaries Makefile" and found this link: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Porting/Conceptual/PortingUnix/compiling/chapter_4_section_3.html
CFLAGS="-isysroot /Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.4u.sdk -arch ppc -arch i386" instead of CFLAGS="-arch ppc -arch i386"
With this the errors disappeared and the Unix "file" command lists the jnilibs now as:
libswt-carbon-3218.jnilib: Mach-O fat file with 2 architectures libswt-carbon-3218.jnilib (for architecture ppc): Mach-O bundle ppc libswt-carbon-3218.jnilib (for architecture i386): Mach-O bundle i386
I haven't tried them on MacIntel yet but they looks promising... Created attachment 31985 waorkspace patch for make_macosx.mak
With this patch make_macosx.mak produces a universal binary on both MacIntel as well as PowerPC. On PowerPC you need to upgrade Xcode to 2.2 and install the Universal SDK. Created attachment 31986 SWT 3218 with universal binaries
SWT 3213 with universal binaries (for 3.2M4) Apple just announced at Macworld the availability of the first Intel IMac in January. I see that you managed to compile SWT as universal binaries. Will that platform be officially supported for the 3.2 release ?
If we could build and test it, we might consider supporting it. We have no hardware. You can build for Intel on PowerPC. I can offer to test on Intel. Created attachment 33023 SWT 3219 with universal binaries
Includes fixes for bug #104892, bug #104902 and bug #122428 (Performance on OS X still degrades on 10.4.3) In order to build a universal binary on PowerPC you have to update MacOS X with the universal SDK which is part of Xcode. The latest Xcode 2.2.1 is available from the ADC site (https://connect.apple.com/). You'l need a free subscription which is available here: http://developer.apple.com/membership/ I have trouble finding an official statement concerning support for intel iMacs. I tried the latest milestone, but it didnt work. I tried to replace the 3219 SWT jar with the one attached to this bug, still the same error message. Anything I can do about it?

So you should be able to run the next integration build out of the box.
The bug stays open until we decide what is the shape of our fragments. The options are:
1 fragment: org.eclipses.swt.carbon.macosx.universal with libraries that are about double of the size
2 fragments: org.eclipse.swt.carbon.macosx.ppc org.eclipse.swt.carbon.macosx.x86
3 fragments: all of the above
My personal opinion is that the 'universal' option is the best as it most closely matches how the platform thinks about binaries and makes it more likely that other native tools for eclipse follow this model. Further, it would be nice to use a single eclipse install on either system type.
(In reply to comment #46) > 1 fragment: > org.eclipses.swt.carbon.macosx.universal > with libraries that are about double of the size For what it's worth, the VM on an Intel machine returns 'ppc' as os.arch, so you won't be able to select on that. Building the SWT with both architectures in one binary is going to be the best option. On the iMac Core Duo it returns i386 for both 1.5 and 1.4.2. What machine and VM are you using that returns an incorrect answer?
(In reply to comment #48) > For what it's worth, the VM on an Intel machine returns 'ppc' as os.arch, so > you won't be able to select on that. Building the SWT with both architectures > in one binary is going to be the best option.
This is news to me -- thanks for pointing it out! A colleague of mine said that we were returning 'ppc', so I took him at his word. I need to follow up on that! Re comment #46: I think a universal binary is the only viable option since processor architecture should be transparent for Mac users (if Eclipse is installed on shared volume, it should work for all clients).
BTW, the size size increase of the (uncompressed) libraries is < 500k and the size increase of the (compressed) swt jar file is about 100k. If someone needs smaller libraries, there are enough tools to strip off the unnecessary part. I think the universal option would be the best, too.
Isn't it true, that eclipse wants to be as platform independent as possible? The fragment concept was only introduced to resolve issues that could not be done well in a generic way. So if we could merge two possible fragments (ppc & x86) into one (universal), this is a step into the right direction imho. I'm a total newbie, taking an intro java course. Hi,
We have the same problem with our application that uses the password function. We are using 3.1.2 with the patch on a iMac core duo. We use the method setEchoChar('*') of a Text control. Because of this bug, the user cannot login to the application.
Patrice Drolet Re comment #64 and #65: I've verified that the universal binary of SWT 3139 in fact contains my workaround for bug #104902. However, this workaround seems only work for Text fields which are created with the SWT.PASSWORD style bit, not by calling Text.setEchoChar. Since Eclipse only uses the former (and IMO more correct) approach, I never experienced the setEchoChar problem and did not provide a workaround for that problem.
So you can either - pass SWT.PASSWORD on Text creation and stop calling Text.setEchoChar(...), or - call Text.setEchoChar(...) and fill the character in both byte halfs of the 16bit character, i.e. setEchoChar((c << 8) + c)
I didn't verify the second approach myself but I think it should work. Note that setEchoChar() is fixed in HEAD. (In reply to comment #67) > Note that setEchoChar() is fixed in HEAD. > It does work with char cbit = (char) (('*' << 8) + '*'); text.setEchoChar(cbit); But it looks terrible on Windows. So I check the os.
It is easier to use this setEchoChar in some part of the code. But I use SWT.PASSWORD too when it is more convenient. Thanks a lot!

The download is of SWT version 3.1.0 and the version with Eclipse 3.1.2 is 3.1.1 (lots of versions, there). Is there a fixed version out there?
This is the released version of 3.1.2, if it helps.
In reply to Comment #64 From Paul Furbacher and Comment #70 From Chris Rose (Chris, BTW, next time it is better to *attach* long stack traces instead ;-) ) which were experiencing pb with the patch SWT 3139 for Eclispe 3.1.2 using attachment from comment #45.
The patched SWT has a version number of 3.1.0. and the standard SWT is 3.1.2. Therefore you are resolving to the old swt instead of the new one. To get to work fine, exit eclipse, move the standard mac os swt jar (version 3.1.2) outside of your plugins dir, put the patched SWT there, and restart with an eclipse -clean.
Or alternatively, patch the manifest witha new version like 3.1.2.1(which I did but did not find appropriate to post here: send me an email if you want the patched version).
It works beautifully on a powerbook 12'' g4 and a macpookpro duo core 15'' with the exact same distro.
And while I am it: ignore my comment Comment #69 on os.arch . The osgi.arch resolves to ppc on a macbook pro, soe everything is fine!
Thanks Andre! Thanks for providing the universal .jnilib files. However, there are two problems with the file java_swt in every version of the universal binaries attached to this bug:
1) it is not executable (not a big deal since you can chmod it yourself) 2) it is not compiled to be universal
I need to get a universal copy of the file java_swt so we can distribute our application to users with intel macs, any suggestions? You don't need java_swt, and it should be removed from the SWT distribution. You just need to use the -XstartOnFirstThread option to the JVM. Created attachment 38343 Universal Binary version of Java_SWT
This is a universal binary compiled version of Java_SWT. (From r3.0 cvs branch) While its no longer nescesary since you can get around it by specifying "StartOnMainThread"
However, for those who still want to use it... here is a unviersal version. (In reply to comment #74) > Created an attachment (id=38343) [edit] > Universal Binary version of Java_SWT > > This is a universal binary compiled version of Java_SWT. (From r3.0 cvs branch)
I must say....thank you very much for posting this! Saved me a bunch of time reworking our launch configuration.
The SWT project should include this binary in their next release! It's not necessary, but it does maintain consistency across releases. Just a FYI, I am shipping a distro on MacOS based on 3.1.2 and we are using Andre's universal binaries from Comment #45 . I works beautifully. Thanks Andre! Note that I patched the manifest so it resolves as a higher version than the standard ppc swt for 3.1.2. I posted the universal binaries with patched manifest here if anybody is interested: http://sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=131065&package_id=183793&release_id=401995 We have decided on how the libraries/fragments should be shipped (see bug#138047), so we are done with the general issue of supporting Mac/Intel. Please open new specific bugs for any problems you find in Mac/Intel. The attachment for 3.1.2 works great when I launch the Eclipse GUI, but when I run standalone, I get a mysterious error, bundle cannot be resolved. I have attached the stacktrace from launching with the following command.
This looks like a bug with the patched jar. I woul dlove to move to 3.2, but our product on top of Eclipse does not work with 3.2 just yet.
If this is not a bug, what am I missing?
Thanks
java -Declipse.consoleLog=true -Dagitar.user.home=. -jar "/Applications/eclipse/startup.jar" -debug -application XXX.com.agitar.eclipse.cmdline.Agitate -p default.arx -nap -tee output.txt -tbsencoding UTF-8 -tbs testtbs/src mdtexample1.Employee
produces the attached stacktrace.

I searched for "Universal Binaries Makefile" and found this link: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Porting/Conceptual/PortingUnix/compiling/chapter_4_section_3.html
CFLAGS="-isysroot /Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.4u.sdk -arch ppc -arch i386" instead of CFLAGS="-arch ppc -arch i386"
With this the errors disappeared and the Unix "file" command lists the jnilibs now as:
libswt-carbon-3218.jnilib: Mach-O fat file with 2 architectures libswt-carbon-3218.jnilib (for architecture ppc): Mach-O bundle ppc libswt-carbon-3218.jnilib (for architecture i386): Mach-O bundle i386
I haven't tried them on MacIntel yet but they looks promising... Created attachment 31985 waorkspace patch for make_macosx.mak

The bug stays open until we decide what is the shape of our fragments. The options are:
1 fragment: org.eclipses.swt.carbon.macosx.universal with libraries that are about double of the size
2 fragments: org.eclipse.swt.carbon.macosx.ppc org.eclipse.swt.carbon.macosx.x86
3 fragments: all of the above
My personal opinion is that the 'universal' option is the best as it most closely matches how the platform thinks about binaries and makes it more likely that other native tools for eclipse follow this model. Further, it would be nice to use a single eclipse install on either system type.
(In reply to comment #46) > 1 fragment: > org.eclipses.swt.carbon.macosx.universal > with libraries that are about double of the size For what it's worth, the VM on an Intel machine returns 'ppc' as os.arch, so you won't be able to select on that. Building the SWT with both architectures in one binary is going to be the best option. On the iMac Core Duo it returns i386 for both 1.5 and 1.4.2. What machine and VM are you using that returns an incorrect answer?
(In reply to comment #48) > For what it's worth, the VM on an Intel machine returns 'ppc' as os.arch, so > you won't be able to select on that. Building the SWT with both architectures > in one binary is going to be the best option.
This is news to me -- thanks for pointing it out! A colleague of mine said that we were returning 'ppc', so I took him at his word. I need to follow up on that! Re comment #46: I think a universal binary is the only viable option since processor architecture should be transparent for Mac users (if Eclipse is installed on shared volume, it should work for all clients).
BTW, the size size increase of the (uncompressed) libraries is < 500k and the size increase of the (compressed) swt jar file is about 100k. If someone needs smaller libraries, there are enough tools to strip off the unnecessary part. I think the universal option would be the best, too.
Isn't it true, that eclipse wants to be as platform independent as possible? The fragment concept was only introduced to resolve issues that could not be done well in a generic way. So if we could merge two possible fragments (ppc & x86) into one (universal), this is a step into the right direction imho. I'm a total newbie, taking an intro java course. Hi,
We have the same problem with our application that uses the password function. We are using 3.1.2 with the patch on a iMac core duo. We use the method setEchoChar('*') of a Text control. Because of this bug, the user cannot login to the application.
Patrice Drolet Re comment #64 and #65: I've verified that the universal binary of SWT 3139 in fact contains my workaround for bug #104902. However, this workaround seems only work for Text fields which are created with the SWT.PASSWORD style bit, not by calling Text.setEchoChar. Since Eclipse only uses the former (and IMO more correct) approach, I never experienced the setEchoChar problem and did not provide a workaround for that problem.
So you can either - pass SWT.PASSWORD on Text creation and stop calling Text.setEchoChar(...), or - call Text.setEchoChar(...) and fill the character in both byte halfs of the 16bit character, i.e. setEchoChar((c << 8) + c)
I didn't verify the second approach myself but I think it should work. Note that setEchoChar() is fixed in HEAD. (In reply to comment #67) > Note that setEchoChar() is fixed in HEAD. > It does work with char cbit = (char) (('*' << 8) + '*'); text.setEchoChar(cbit); But it looks terrible on Windows. So I check the os.
It is easier to use this setEchoChar in some part of the code. But I use SWT.PASSWORD too when it is more convenient. Thanks a lot!

In reply to Comment #64 From Paul Furbacher and Comment #70 From Chris Rose (Chris, BTW, next time it is better to *attach* long stack traces instead ;-) ) which were experiencing pb with the patch SWT 3139 for Eclispe 3.1.2 using attachment from comment #45.
The patched SWT has a version number of 3.1.0. and the standard SWT is 3.1.2. Therefore you are resolving to the old swt instead of the new one. To get to work fine, exit eclipse, move the standard mac os swt jar (version 3.1.2) outside of your plugins dir, put the patched SWT there, and restart with an eclipse -clean.
Or alternatively, patch the manifest witha new version like 3.1.2.1(which I did but did not find appropriate to post here: send me an email if you want the patched version).
It works beautifully on a powerbook 12'' g4 and a macpookpro duo core 15'' with the exact same distro.
And while I am it: ignore my comment Comment #69 on os.arch . The osgi.arch resolves to ppc on a macbook pro, soe everything is fine!

Bug.Summery: print in breakpoint
Bug.WithStack:
Hello, I would suggest an improvement of the breakpoint feature in debugging. We could have the following behavior , ie a breakpoint which doesn't stop when the condition is reached, but which on display an expression on the console. For example, I could have "displaypoint" set on a specific line of my programm, and whenever this line is reached, I could display in the console or expression view a result combining variables visible at this point... Obviously we could do that with AJDT, but it is too complicated for only this feature. regards Xavier You can do it now with a conditional breakpoint. Create an condition like
System.out.println("something"); return false;
The breakpoint will not suspend as the "condition" is false.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 71020 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
Hello, I would suggest an improvement of the breakpoint feature in debugging. We could have the following behavior , ie a breakpoint which doesn't stop when the condition is reached, but which on display an expression on the console. For example, I could have "displaypoint" set on a specific line of my programm, and whenever this line is reached, I could display in the console or expression view a result combining variables visible at this point... Obviously we could do that with AJDT, but it is too complicated for only this feature. regards Xavier You can do it now with a conditional breakpoint. Create an condition like
System.out.println("something"); return false;
The breakpoint will not suspend as the "condition" is false.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 71020 ***

Bug.Summery: DataSet data preview has low performance

Lines.Line: (1) Did you run identical SQLs when you compare BIRT preview performance with
DBVisualizer? Does DBVisualizer use JDBC, and if so is it using the same JDBC
drivers as BIRT?
(2) Can you attach the content of the SQL that runs slowly to this bug?
(3) What's the Java VM heap size setting you use to start Eclipse? Does the
performance problem persist if you double the heap size? (Use the "-vmargs
-Xmx512m" argument on Eclipse command line to set heap size to 512MB for example).

Bug.WithStack:
The number of rows fetched from database should be limitted when creating or modifying a datasource.
Currently it seems like BIRT is retrieving all the rows from the table, and (in our scenario) it's a huge table. As the row fetching blocks user operations, it impacts usability quite badly (maybe the rows could be displayed from a background worker thread?).
It should be an option on the BIRT preferences page.
A similar option should be available for limiting the number of rows retrieved while previewing the report (with a button per datasource to "Show all", if there are more rows than those shown). Moved to 1.0.1 as a requested improvement. Added keywords. Data set preview already limits result set to first 500 rows. Can you please verify if this is working for you?
The suggested enhancements make sense. The preview row limit should be user configurable. It will also be nice to add a "More rows" or "Show all" button in the preview pane. Sorry, the data displayed is certainly not the full table contents.
However, BIRT is very slow retrieving the preview data, and the usability issues remain.
Using another tool (DBVisualizer) to query the table, limitting the result to 30.000 tuples, it takes about 20 seconds (during which, a counter is updated every 100 tuples, so the user knows that the app is working).
Using BIRT preview, it takes more than 4 minutes for 500 tuples, with no perceived progress and freezing Eclipse.
For the record, the table contains 36 columns, 30 of them are VARCHAR(50), 3 are TIMESTAMP and 3 are BIGINT. Most of the VARCHARs are NULL. The table has a total of 30.747.214 rows.
I'm changing the title to something more relevant.
A couple more questions: (1) Did you run identical SQLs when you compare BIRT preview performance with DBVisualizer? Does DBVisualizer use JDBC, and if so is it using the same JDBC drivers as BIRT? (2) Can you attach the content of the SQL that runs slowly to this bug? (3) What's the Java VM heap size setting you use to start Eclipse? Does the performance problem persist if you double the heap size? (Use the "-vmargs -Xmx512m" argument on Eclipse command line to set heap size to 512MB for example).
Sorry for the late response...
I've traced this to a parameter in the conection string. My DB is an SQLServer (with the MS provided JDBC driver) and I was using the parameter "connectionMethod=cursor" with DBVisualizer, but not with BIRT.
This parameter changes between the way data is sent to the client. With "cursor" method, the preview runs much faster.
The difference is that "cursor" opens a DB cursor which is used to read the data under demand. If it is not specified, de DB feeds the whole data to the client (so it doesn't care how many rows are actually read).
(I'm not 100% sure of my own explanation, but the point is that, with similar conenction strings, BIRT preview and DBVisualizer run with equivalent response times).
I'm marking the bug as INVALID.
For the record, I'll answer the questions you asked:
(In reply to comment #4) > (1) Did you run identical SQLs when you compare BIRT preview performance with > DBVisualizer? Yes. > Does DBVisualizer use JDBC, and if so is it using the same JDBC > drivers as BIRT? Yes. > (2) Can you attach the content of the SQL that runs slowly to this bug? I'll paste it, as it is really simple... select * from gnsql0.GNVATMHQ where VTME_IT_TSCarga > '23/06/2005'
> (3) What's the Java VM heap size setting you use to start Eclipse? Does the > performance problem persist if you double the heap size? (Use the "-vmargs > -Xmx512m" argument on Eclipse command line to set heap size to 512MB for example). It was already set at that level.
Vierified in the Build 20051220
